conclusion: Use principles of ideal gas behavior to solve the problem.
Gas undergoes a process from state A to state B and then to state C.
Temperature at state A is 27°C, which is 300 K.
State A has a pressure of 10^4 Pa and a volume of 10^-3 m³.
State B has a pressure of 10^4 Pa and a volume of 3.0 × 10^-3 m³.
State C has a pressure of 10^4 Pa and a volume of 3.0 × 10^-3 m³.
Calculate change in temperature from state A to state B using constant pressure.
Calculate change in volume from state B to state C using constant pressure.
Calculate final volume at state C: 6.0 × 10^-3 m³.
Calculate heat transferred by the gas using change in internal energy.
Heat transferred is calculated using Q = n × C_p × ΔT.
Assume specific heat capacity C_p is constant to calculate heat transferred.
Repeated calculation of heat transferred assuming constant C_p.
Repeated calculation of heat transferred assuming constant C_p.
Repeated calculation of heat transferred assuming constant C_p.
Repeated calculation of heat transferred assuming constant C_p.
Repeated calculation of heat transferred assuming constant C_p.
Repeated calculation of heat transferred assuming constant C_p.
Repeated calculation of heat transferred assuming constant C_p.
Repeated calculation of heat transferred assuming constant C_p.
